The Day After

The last nine weeks have been one of the most dynamic experiences I’ve willingly placed myself in. When I started the Dev Bootcamp experience I focused mainly on the code, the programming and the technical skills I would gain in the process. Now on the other end, I realize it was so much more than that.

July 20, 2014Ernie Salazar  •  Comment Reading time ~2 minutes

Time Commitment

I spent 80 hours of this past week physically at Dev Bootcamp’s San Francisco location. In addition, I likely spent another 20 plus hours working on projects from home. While on campus, I was never the first to arrive and not nearly the last to leave. I knew coming into the program that much would be expected, including my time. While It’s been tiring at times, it’s also more rewarding than I ever imagined.

July 06, 2014Ernie Salazar  •  Comment Reading time ~2 minutes

Wait, What?

So we’ve been told that confusion is a stage of learning. Without it, there’s no opening for new knowledge or information. I hope that’s true, as this is where I spent most of my time this past week. Right when I thought a concept was clear or a solution at hand, it was proved otherwise. While that may seem discouraging, there were also sparks of clarity (few, but they were there).

June 29, 2014Ernie Salazar  •  Comment Reading time ~2 minutes

Celebration

With my first full week at Dev Bootcamp in the books, I can look back and celebrate. It’s been a challenging experience so far and I have a feeling that this past week was the easiest week of them all. It’s an educational experience completely different than anything I’ve been apart of. Despite the long days and little sleep, I can’t wait to wake up tomorrow and do it all over again.

June 21, 2014Ernie Salazar  •  Comment Reading time ~2 minutes

Taking the Headphones Off

As part of the application process for Dev Bootcamp, I took a quick test to determine my personal thinking style. It’s based on the research of Anthony Gregorc which is theorized into the Gregorc Mind Styles. These mind styles can help illuminate, not only how a particular person thinks, but also how they learn.
